content:
AUSTRALIA

Automotive Holdings (AHG AT)
- Co. guides FY18 oper. profit at around AUD 75mln vs. Exp. AUD 86mln. (Newswires)

Bluescope Steel (BSL AT)
- Co. raises H2 guidance in which it sees prior underlying EBIT to be about 25% higher. (Newswires)

Galaxy Resources (GXY AT)
- Co. gives update on Sal de Vida project which it sees costing AUD 474mln and has a NPV of AUD 1.48bln at 8% discount. (Newswires)

Link Administration Holdings (LNK AT)
- Co. said it is exploring options with Pexa in which it is the 2nd largest shareholder of. (Newswires)

Ruralco Holdings (RHL AT)
- Co. H1 net profit attributable rose 29.2% Y/Y to AUD 16.1mln, while revenue rose 7% Y/Y to AUD 919.9mln. (Newswires)

Wesfarmers (WES AT)
- Co. is looking at exit options for Kmart Tyre & Auto Service business. (AFR)

Whitehaven Coal (WHC AT)
- Co. completes previously announced purchase of 30% stake in Tarrawonga mine from Idemitsu (5019 JT). (Newswires)

WorleyParsons (WOR AT)
- Co. receives contract extension from Maersk UK and that it received General Engineering Service contract from Yanbu Aramco Sinopec Refining Co. (Newswires)

Basic Materials / Energy
- Spot gold declined 0.3%.
- Iron ore rose 2.2%.
- WTI rose back above USD 71.00/bbl and Brent crude gained 1.6% to above USD 78.00/bbl. (Newswires)

JAPAN

Fujitsu (6702 JT)
- Co. is said to utilize blockchain technology for Virtora DX data distribution and utilization service. (Newswires)

Isuzu Motors (7202 JT)
- Co. FY17/18 net JPY 105.7bln vs. Prev. JPY 93.9bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Kaneka (4118 JT)
- Co. acquires nearly 35% stake in Spanish biotech firm AB-Biotics. (Newswires)

Mitsubishi Estate (8802 JT)
- Co. FY17/18 net JPY 120.4bln vs. Prev. JPY 102.7bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (8306 JT)
- Co. plans to make its board consist of a majority of external directors. (Newswires)

Nissan (7201 JT)
- Co. FY17/18 net JPY 747bln vs. Exp. JPY 727bln, guides FY18/19 net JPY 500bln vs. Exp. JPY 570bln. (Newswires)
- Co. is mulling several options with Renault (RNO FP) such as a more balanced equity structure to ensure continuity of their alliance. (Nikkei)

- Co. FY17/18 net rose 3.9% Y/Y to JPY 734.37bln. (Newswires)

Takeda Pharmaceutical (4502 JT)
- Co. FY17/18 net JPY 186.9bln vs. Prev. JPY 114.9bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Automakers / Property

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
UK

UK PM May reportedly admitted that current options regarding UK customs plan are unworkable. (Telegraph)

EU’s Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier told EU ministers that not much progress has been made in Brexit talks following the previous leaders summit, while Barnier also repeated that there is no transition deal without an exit deal. (Newswires)


EU

Italy's President Mattarella gave more time to the 5SM and the League to work out a government deal with no deadline set according to a presidential source, while there were also reports that the League party are set to hold informal referendum on 19th and 20th of May for members to approve an eventual government deal with 5-Star Movement. (Newswires)

ECB's Coeure reiterated the governing council's view that the key policy rates are to remain at current levels for an extended period of time and well beyond the end of QE. (Newswires)


COMMODITIES

WTI futures (June) settle 26 cents higher at $70.96 per barrel; Brent futures (July) settle $1.11 higher at $78.23 per barrel. Brent outperformed WTI on Monday, with traders citing concerns about the geopolitical situation in the Middle East, driving the spread between the two benchmarks to wides last seen in 2015. Yemini rebels were once again reported to have been firing missiles at Saudi Aramco facilities. The crude complex started out the week in quiet fashion in the APAC session, with the bias towards selling after weekend news from the UAE, where the energy minister said that OPEC (Saudi, Kuwait and UEA) has the capacity to plug any gaps in production caused by Iran sanctions. Analysts have been considering how many barrels will be taken-off the market, and the range of estimates is wide – some believe it could be minimal, while others like the BP Boss Dudley suggest it could be as high as 1mln BPD. Also over the weekend, US National Security Advisor Bolton threatened European companies and nations who continue to do business with Iran could be hit with US sanctions. Additionally, traders were also chewing the fat on Baker Hughes weekly rig count data, released on Friday, which showed oil drillers adding 10 rigs in the week. On Monday, OPEC’s monthly report intimated that the global oil glut is nearly over; crude production rose 12k bpd in April to average 31.93mln bpd, according to secondary sources; higher production in Saudi Arabia and Algeria was partially offset by decreased crude oil production, mainly in Venezuela, Gabon and Nigeria. OPEC also said that 2018 oil demand growth is forecast to increase by around 1.65 mb/d to average 98.85 mln bpd, while OECD commercial stocks declined in March, leaving the surplus just 9mln barrels above its five-year average. Analysts forecast crude oil inventories will draw down for the second consecutive week, with the Street estimating headline crude to draw 1.5mln, distillates to draw 1.8mln, gasoline to draw 1.1mln; meanwhile, Genscape reportedly has forecast stocks at Cushing will show a modest build of 65k barrels this week.


GEOPOLITICAL

North Korea has started to dismantle its Punggye-Ri test site. (Twitter)


US

US President Trump and Canadian PM Trudeau discussed via phone call the possibility of a quick NAFTA agreement, while the White House said that US President Trump urged a prompt NAFTA agreement during the phone call. (Newswires)

US & China are reportedly closing in on a deal which would give ZTE a reprieve from US sanctions, in exchange for Beijing removing tariffs on billions of US agricultural products, according to people familiar with the matter. (Newswires)

US Commerce Secretary Ross accused China and Europe of being highly protectionist and accused China of stealing intellectual as well as forcing tech transfers. Ross also commented that China hasn’t obliged to rules since joining the WTO and warned that agricultural tariffs will come at China’s cost. Ross further stated the US will be impose EU steel tariffs if no deal is met before June 1st, while he also commented key NAFTA topics remain a work in progress. (Newswires)

Fed's Mester (Voter, Hawk) said does not expect inflation to pick up sharply and that she supports gradual rise in US interest rates, while Mester stated she does not think rates will be hiked beyond 3% in the ‘near future’. (Newswires)

Fed's Bullard (Non-Voter, Dove) said the USD is in great shape and is a long-term winner, while he also repeated his concerns on possible yield curve inversion and warned that the Fed should not raise rates aggressively. (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

US Equity futures traded higher overnight, slightly building on Friday’s gains. However, as the US cash market opened futures caught a further bid, but it was short-lived, and the Emini struggled to make ground above 2740, after which futures then fell gradually throughout the rest of the session to relatively flat levels by the market close, though the trading range and volumes were thinnish. In M&A news, Xerox (XRX) announced it had ended its $6.1bln deal with Fujifilm in a settlement with two of its largest shareholders, Carl Icahn and Darwin Deason, which saw the stock hit intraday low of ~9% before paring back some of the losses as trade progressed to the close. CBS (CBS) and Viacom (VIAB), CBS filed a lawsuit to protect and give voting power to stockholders; lawsuit seeks to prevent National Amusements from interfering in special meeting where board is considering declaring a dividend, an attempt to dilute the controlling voting power of Shari Redstone, who is trying to force CBS (CBS) to re-merge with Viacom (VIAB).  Finally, China has restarted the review of Qualcomm’s (QCOM) USD 44bln offer for NXP Semiconductors (NXPI). Elsewhere, Symantec outperformed on Monday following reports it is to hold a press conference addressing the latest probe it is facing. Also, of note for some casino names (SGMS, CZR, PENN & MGM), the group did benefit from an announcement that New Jersey can legalise sports betting, however the main gains were seen in UK gambling names such as William Hill (WMH LN) and Paddy Power (PPB LN). The larger casino names (WYNN & LVS) did initially benefit on the news however the gains were pared back. Elsewhere, US President Trump tweeted he is working with China’s president Xi to give ZTE a way back into business, this boosted some companies with heavy exposure to the name such as Acacia Communications (ACIA) and Oclaro (OCLR). SPX +0.09% at 2730, NDX +0.17% at 6964, DJI +0.29% at 24902.

Treasuries were slightly down on Monday, albeit amid thin volume, with some suggesting early moves were in sympathy with German bunds, after a slate of ECB’s speak appeared a touch more upbeat about the Eurozone economy, helping bund yields rise. Others attributed the selling action to a deep pipeline of investment grade debt, with the likes of Keurig launching an $8bln six-part M&A bond sale to finance it's Dr Pepper M&A. Most of the Treasury action was concentrated in the belly of the curve, with 5yr and 10yr yields higher by c.2bps at settlement. Although some steepening was seen across the complex heading into the close, 5s30s spread was only just off cyclical lows, steepening by c.1bp, while 2s10, 2s30s steeper by around 2bps. US 10yr T-Notes futures settled 5 ticks lower at 119-80

UBS Weekly FX Flows: GBP buying interest amid EUR selling
content:
• EURUSD: EURUSD was net bought, as buying interest from asset managers and hedge funds outweighed selling from private clients and corporates.
  • USDJPY,  EURJPY:  JPY saw inflows vs USD for the first time in five weeks, as all client groups  except  private  clients  bought  JPY.  EURJPY  flows  were  more  or  less  flat,  as  inflows  from  asset  managers  and  private  clients  were  offset  by  outflows  from  hedge  funds and corporates.
  • GBPUSD, EURGBP: GBPUSD was net bought, as all the client groups registered inflows except for corporates. GBP recorded strong buying interest vs EUR as corporate selling was muted by inflows from all other client groups. 
  • EURCHF,  USDCHF:  CHF  was  sold  vs  EUR,  as  asset  manager  inflows  were  more  than  offset by outflows from all other clients. USDCHF was net bought, as heavy corporate inflows exceeded selling from all other client groups.
  • AUDUSD,  NZDUSD,  and  USDCAD:  AUDUSD  recorded  inflows  as  asset  manager  buying outweighed hedge fund and corporate client selling. NZDUSD was sold for the fourth  straight  week,  led  by  hedge  fund  selling,  while  all  other  clients  showed  limited  directionality.  CAD  saw  inflows  versus  USD  as  buying  interest  from  hedge  funds  and  asset managers exceeded marginal selling from private clients and corporates.
  • EURSEK,  EURNOK,  USDSEK,  and  USDNOK:  SEK saw outflows versus EUR as selling by asset managers exceeded buying by hedge funds. EURNOK was net sold as outflows from  asset  managers  exceeded  inflows  from  all  other  client  groups.  USDSEK  was  heavily bought for a 7th straight week, led by asset managers. USDNOK was net sold as asset manager-led outflows overwhelmed mild inflows from hedge funds.

subject: US MARKET WRAP 14 May 2018: Ross on China trade, Fed’s speak, OPEC MOMR
content:
• * SNAP-SHOT: Equities slightly higher, Treasuries flat, DXY up, Crude up
  • * REAR-VIEW: Ross on trade, Italy working on a government, Fed and ECB speak, OPEC monthly report
  • * AHEAD: RBA Minutes overnight, UK Labour Market Data (Tues), German ZEW (Tues), EZ GDP (Tues), US Retail Sales (Tues), Home Depot reports numbers on Tues.
  •  

* TRADE: US Commerce Secretary Ross largely reiterated the Trump administration hard line views, arguing that not all trade deficits are the same, and said ‘artificial deficits’ are ‘blameful and shameful’. Ross added that China hasn’t complied with WTO rules since joining the organisation, and he again accused the country of stealing intellectual property and forcing technology transfers. Ross blamed China and Europe of being ‘highly protectionist’ countries, warning that China’s agricultural tariffs will come at its own cost, and the impact on the US economy would be minimal. He also noted that the distance between US and China positions on trade remain some distance apart. He also commented on the ZTE story, noting his department sees it as an “enforcement action” which remains separate from “trade action.” Finally, on NAFTA, key topics remain a “work in progress.”

* ITALIAN POLITICS: Italy President Mattarella held formation talks with the 5 Star Movement  and with the League on Monday. After significant progress was made over the weekend, the two parties have reached an agreement on measures including universal basic income, a flat tax and roll back of pension reforms, although uncertainty still remains on the new PM and new cabinet members. Italian Economist Sapelli (proposed by the League) is no longer running for the PM role, leaving Conte (proposed by the 5SM) a more likely candidate for the position, some suggest. League’s leader Salvini later in the day that work is still needed on a government plan, noting that there was still no deal on government issues. Italy's President has given more time to the two parties to work out a deal, and has not set any deadlines. Italy’s League is set to hold informal referendum on 19-20 May for its members to approve an eventual government deal with 5-Star Movement.

* FED SPEAK: Fed's Mester (Voter, Hawk) does not expect inflation to pick up sharply and she supports gradual rise in US interest rates. Mester does not think rates will be hiked beyond 3% in the ‘near future’. Fed's Bullard (Non-Voter, Dove) said the Dollar is in great shape and is a long-term winner, and elsewhere repeated his concerns on possible yield curve inversion, warning that the Fed should not raise rates aggressively.

*ECB SPEAK: ECB’s Villeroy (Dovish) noted the end of net asset purchases is nearing, but whether this is in September or December is not an existential question. Underlying inflation has temporarily slowed down, but it is set to strengthen irrespective of short-run fluctuations in energy inflation.  Communication will be adjusted given current rate guidance is conditioned on the end of net asset purchases, Villeroy said, and it could give additional guidance on timing of rate hike – he tilted positively his tone noting that "well past" seeming some quarters rather than years. ECB’s Lautenschlager (Hawk) expressed confidence in underlying inflation trends, adding the Eurozone economy is still within ECB projections. Incoming ECB member Rehn said short term indicators suggest the pace of growth has somewhat cooled in the early months of this year, arguing that this could be temporary, but data is signalling a slowdown in growth. Overall, however, the economic outlook for the Euro area is strong, however. (Note: Rehn is to take Liikanen's position on the ECB's Governing Council in July).

* EQUITIES: SPX +0.09% at 2730, NDX +0.17% at 6964, DJI +0.29% at 24902.  SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals: +0.11%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: +0.17%, Energy: +0.56%, Financials: -0.09%, Health Care: +0.46%, Industrials: -0.19%, Materials: +0.28%, Technology: +0.07%, Telecoms: -0.44%, Utilities: -0.62%.

US Equity futures traded higher overnight, slightly building on Friday’s gains. However, as the US cash market opened futures caught a further bid, but it was short-lived, and the Emini struggled to make ground above 2740, after which futures then fell gradually throughout the rest of the session to relatively flat levels by the market close, though the trading range and volumes were thinnish.

* M&A news: Xerox (XRX) announced it had ended its $6.1bln deal with Fujifilm in a settlement with two of its largest shareholders, Carl Icahn and Darwin Deason, which saw the stock hit intraday low of ~9% before paring back some of the losses as trade progressed to the close. CBS (CBS) and Viacom (VIAB), CBS filed a lawsuit to protect and give voting power to stockholders; lawsuit seeks to prevent National Amusements from interfering in special meeting where board is considering declaring a dividend, an attempt to dilute the controlling voting power of Shari Redstone, who is trying to force CBS (CBS) to re-merge with Viacom (VIAB).  Finally, China has restarted the review of Qualcomm’s (QCOM) USD 44bln offer for NXP Semiconductors (NXPI).

* Stock specific news: Symantec outperformed on Monday following reports it is to hold a press conference addressing the latest probe it is facing. Also, of note for some casino names (SGMS, CZR, PENN & MGM), the group did benefit from an announcement that New Jersey can legalise sports betting, however the main gains were seen in UK gambling names such as William Hill (WMH LN) and Paddy Power (PPB LN). The larger casino names (WYNN & LVS) did initially benefit on the news however the gains were pared back. Elsewhere, US President Trump tweeted he is working with China’s president Xi to give ZTE a way back into business, this boosted some companies with heavy exposure to the name such as Acacia Communications (ACIA) and Oclaro (OCLR). 

* CRUDE: WTI futures (June) settle 26 cents higher at $70.96 per barrel; Brent futures (July) settle $1.11 higher at $78.23 per barrel. Brent outperformed WTI on Monday, with traders citing concerns about the geopolitical situation in the Middle East, driving the spread between the two benchmarks to wides last seen in 2015. Yemini rebels were once again reported to have been firing missiles at Saudi Aramco facilities. The crude complex started out the week in quiet fashion in the APAC session, with the bias towards selling after weekend news from the UAE, where the energy minister said that OPEC (Saudi, Kuwait and UEA) has the capacity to plug any gaps in production caused by Iran sanctions. Analysts have been considering how many barrels will be taken-off the market, and the range of estimates is wide – some believe it could be minimal, while others like the BP Boss Dudley suggest it could be as high as 1mln BPD. Also over the weekend, US National Security Advisor Bolton threatened European companies and nations who continue to do business with Iran could be hit with US sanctions. Additionally, traders were also chewing the fat on Baker Hughes weekly rig count data, released on Friday, which showed oil drillers adding 10 rigs in the week. On Monday, OPEC’s monthly report intimated that the global oil glut is nearly over; crude production rose 12k bpd in April to average 31.93mln bpd, according to secondary sources; higher production in Saudi Arabia and Algeria was partially offset by decreased crude oil production, mainly in Venezuela, Gabon and Nigeria. OPEC also said that 2018 oil demand growth is forecast to increase by around 1.65 mb/d to average 98.85 mln bpd, while OECD commercial stocks declined in March, leaving the surplus just 9mln barrels above its five-year average. Analysts forecast crude oil inventories will draw down for the second consecutive week, with the Street estimating headline crude to draw 1.5mln, distillates to draw 1.8mln, gasoline to draw 1.1mln; meanwhile, Genscape reportedly has forecast stocks at Cushing will show a modest build of 65k barrels this week.

* TREASURIES: US 10yr T-Notes futures settled 5 ticks lower at 119-80. Treasuries were slightly down on Monday, albeit amid thin volume, with some suggesting early moves were in sympathy with German bunds, after a slate of ECB’s speak appeared a touch more upbeat about the Eurozone economy, helping bund yields rise. Others attributed the selling action to a deep pipeline of investment grade debt, with the likes of Keurig launching an $8bln six-part M&A bond sale to finance it's Dr Pepper M&A. Most of the Treasury action was concentrated in the belly of the curve, with 5yr and 10yr yields higher by c.2bps at settlement. Although some steepening was seen across the complex heading into the close, 5s30s spread was only just off cyclical lows, steepening by c.1bp, while 2s10, 2s30s steeper by around 2bps.

* FOREX: DXY tested fresh post-US CPI lows amidst widespread Greenback losses before gleaning a degree of traction from the latest upturn in Treasury yields that appears more supply related, given a raft of corporate deals and institutional issuance. The DXY dipped towards 92.200 before stabilising; in afternoon trade, the USD did find strength, however, pushing EUR beneath 1.1950, and gains were particularly stark against the CAD, NZD and AUD; there wasn’t a specific story for the USD buying, though some had cited stops, and some also tried to connect Wilbur Ross’ comments on the USD (it plays a role in trade deficits) to the moves, given that the highs were made immediately after Ross’ comments.  

* GBP, EUR, CHF: All were challenging/testing some key levels vs the Dollar as GBP crosses 1.3600 again, with stops touted from 1.3610 – we never quite got to that level however, and the late USD strength pushed cable towards 1.3550. EUR has inched closer to 1.2000 and its 200 DMA at 1.2020 following some upbeat/hawkish ECB commentary (Villeroy initially and then Lautenschlaeger) and progress on the Italian Government coalition formation (albeit limited), though fell victim to the USD strength, moving towards neutral levels. CHF recoiled further from parity-plus recent peaks to just a few pips off 0.9950, and seemingly paying little heed to SNB policy guidance maintaining that rates will remain negative and Franc strength will be curbed by direct action as it is still deemed to be overvalued.

* JPY: A relative underperformer, with USDJPY on the brink of breaching a short term chart level and 50% Fib between 109.59-60.

* CAD, AUD: Benefitted from the USD misfortune in early trade, and CAD was also underpinned by oil and NAFTA deal hopes. AUDUSD was holding near 0.7550, well above recent lows and the latest big option expiries at 0.7500 that ran off unscathed, with further support coming via cross moves vs the NZD (which has inched over the 200 DMA at 1.0881), though fell beneath 0.7550 in late trade.

* EM: Intervention and some simple short covering against the backdrop of broad dollar retracement helped the likes of the ARS, RUB and TRY regain some composure.

*COMING-UP: RBA MINUTES (overnight): The RBA’s minutes are unlikely to diverge too far from the latest RBA statement. At the meeting, they kept interest rate unchanged at 1.50% and Governor Lowe said there was not a strong case for a near term move in rates. With the RBA expected to remain on hold for the foreseeable future, the minutes are not expected to have a major impact on Australian assets. On the same day, RBA Deputy Governor Debelle speaks and these comments may be more interesting given that the speech is on the outlook for the Australian economy. Debelle last spoke in the middle of April but didn’t mention monetary policy in his speech.

* COMING UP - US RETAIL SALES (Tues): The Street looks for US retail sales to rise 0.4% MM in April (vs previous 0.6%) and the control group to rise by 0.3% MM (vs previous 0.4%). Analysts are expecting the slight cooling in the pace of growth to be attributed to softer vehicle sales, though the rise in gasoline prices will perhaps offset some of that weakness. Retail sales growth in Q1 slowed to around 1.0% annualised, according to Capital Economics. “Nonetheless, with incomes boosted by the recent tax cuts and a strong labour market, the conditions are in place for spending growth to pick up again in the second quarter.”

* COMING UP - UK LABOUR MARKET DATA (Tues): Over in the UK, Tuesday brings the release of the latest domestic labour report with focus once again set to fall on the earnings components with unemployment near historic lows. Earnings will gain extra prominence in the wake of last month’s decline in earnings and last week’s ‘confusing’ BoE release which has left traders looking for clues as to when the BoE could deliver their next 25bps hike, albeit that call is more likely to be made based on revisions to Q1 GDP. Ahead of the report, RBC note “it appears that the including bonus measure will be unchanged from last month at 2.8% 3m/y but base effects could see the ex-bonus measure slow to 2.6% 3m/y”.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Dollar in doldrums as most G10 rivals and some Ems regroup
content:
DXY

The index tested fresh post-US CPI lows amidst widespread Greenback losses before gleaning a degree of traction from the latest upturn in Treasury yields that appears more supply related given a raft of corporate deals and institutional issuance. The DXY dipped towards 92.200 before stabilising, but remains pressured while below 92.500 with nothing major in the way of chart support until just below the next big downside figure/round number.

GBP/EUR/CHF

The G10 outperformers and challenging/testing some key levels vs the Dollar as Cable crosses 1.3600 again, with stops touted from 1.3610, while Eur/Usd has inched closer to 1.2000 and its 200 DMA at 1.2020 following some upbeat/hawkish ECB commentary (Villeroy initially and then Lautenschlaeger) and progress on the Italian Government coalition formation (albeit limited ahead of meetings between President Mattarella, 5-Star and League parties due to kick-off shortly). However, Usd/Chf has recoiled further from parity-plus recent peaks to just a few pips off 0.9950, and seemingly paying little heed to SNB policy guidance maintaining that rates will remain negative and Franc strength will be curbed by direct action as it is still deemed to be overvalued.

CAD/AUD

Also benefiting from the Usd’s demise, and with the Loonie also underpinned by oil and NAFTA deal hopes within a 1.2800-1.2750 broad range. Aud/Usd holding near 0.7550, well above recent lows and the latest big option expiries at 0.7500 that ran off unscathed, with further support coming via cross moves vs the NZD, which has inched over the 200 DMA (1.0881).

JPY

Another relative underperformer, with Usd/Jpy on the brink of breaching a short term chart level and 50% Fib between 109.59-60.

EM

Intervention and some simple short covering against the backdrop of broad Dollar retracement helped the likes of the ARS, RUB and TRY regain some composure.

• This follows reports that Italy’s 5-Star Movement and League reached an agreement on measures including universal basic income, a flat tax and roll back of pension reforms from 2011.

JP Morgan (JPM) – The bank said it sent an application to a Chinese securities regulator, so it can set up a securities business where JPM would own 51%, allowing its corporate and investment banking divisions to seek more clients in China. (Newswires)

Goldman Sachs (GS) – The bank is looking to expand its Marcus consumer bank unit throughout Europe and has chosen Germany to follow its UK launch. (FT)

Walmart (WMT) – The co. is evaluating an IPO for Flipkart which could come in four years. Separately, the CEO is looking for more deals after its Flipkart investment.  (Newswires)

S&P500

Baker Hughes (BHGE) – The energy co. entered talks with Adnoc regarding a potential drilling partnership, according to people familiar with the matter. (Newswires)

BlackRock (BLK) – The co. is allowed to keep fees from Ohio after a donation to Governor John Kasich’s presidential campaign, according to a preliminary ruling of a security regulator. (Newswires)

Boston Scientific (BSX) – The co. released data demonstrating success of SMART Pass for patients implanted with the EMBLEM Subcutaneous Implantable Defibrillator System. (Newswires)

ConocoPhillips (COP) – According to sources, the oil group is looking to sell its fields in the North Sea as it aims to focus its operation in its home country, the sale could reach up to USD 2bln. Separately, the co. seized products from Venezuela’s PDVSA, Isla refinery. (Newswires)

Cummins (CMI) – The co. and Anhui Jianghuai Automobile Co. are to form a 50:50 joint-venture after the co.’s purchased Navistar's (NAV) 50% equity of the JAC-Navistar Diesel Engine company. (Newswires)

Eli Lilly (LLY) – The co. is to acquire all shares of Aurka Pharma, who will receive an upfront payment of USD 110mln, and the shareholders are eligible to receive up to USD 465mln in regulatory and sales milestones. Eli Lilly see no change to earnings results following the acquisition. (Newswires)

Ford (F) – The automaker is to resume the production of F-150 on May 18 in Dearborn and Kansas City. (Newswires)

Medtronic (MDT) – The medical co. announced results from its MARVEL study, where it says it was ‘encouraged’. (Newswires)

Monsanto (MON) – Bayer’s (BAYN GY) CFO told German press that Bayer’s potential synergies from buying Monsanto will be lower than USD 1.5bln due to antitrust divestments. (Newswires)

Oracle (ORCL) – The board of directors has elected and added Charles Moorman IV and William Parrett to the board. (Newswires)

Perrigo (PRGO) – The co. does not expect to launch the ProAir Inhalation Aerosol by Q4, as previously scheduled. (Newswires)

Regions Financial (RF) -  CFO David J. Turner sold 46,374 common shares. (Newswires)

Xerox (XRX) - The co. reported on Sunday it has ended its USD 6.1bln deal with Fujifilm in a settlement with investors Carl Icahn and Darwin Deason. (Newswires)

Barron’s noted AT&T (T), Exxon Mobil (XOM), Procter & Gamble (PG), Kimberly-Clark (KMB), Coca-Cola (KO), Consolidated Edison (ED), Cardinal Health (CAH), Leggett & Platt (LEG), Chevron (CVX), Target (TGT), Federal Realty Investment Trust (FRT) and PepsiCo (PEP) presented high yields and annual dividend increases for the past 25 years or more. Tesla (TSLA) - Matthew Schwall, the automaker’s director of field performance engineering, left the co. and moved to Alphabet’s (GOOGL) self-driving unit Waymo, according to people familiar the decision. Separately, head of engineering Doug Field is taking a break from the automaker. The automaker registered a new electric vehicle firm in China before limits on foreign ownership of new-energy vehicle ventures kick in. (WSJ/ Newswires)

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 14th May 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Eur and Gbp leading broad gains vs the Usd, as DXY remains close to recent lows sub-92.500
  • Italian President Mattarella to hold government formation talks with 5 Star at 16:30 (15:30 BST), with League at 18:00 (17:00 BST)
  • Looking ahead, highlights include the OPEC Monthly Report (05:40 CDT/11:40 BST), Fed’s Bullard, ECB’s Praet, Lautenschlaeger, Coeure and Italian government formation talks

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets began the week mostly positive but with trade relatively rangebound following Friday’s mixed performance on Wall St, where stocks saw an indecisive finish to their best week since March. In addition, US equity futures also received a modest uplift after US President Trump provided a lifeline for ZTE over the weekend as he vowed to get the Chinese telco back to business in a surprising policy U-turn after the Co. had announced a halt to major operating activities following a US 7-year supply ban order. ASX 200 (+0.3%) was positive with M&A activity underpinning Healthscope, while Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) was also in the green as earnings remained in focus with Shiseido among the index leaders on record Q1 sales. Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) and Hang Seng (+1.4%) conformed to the broad risk appetite as trade concerns eased following the ZTE policy reversal by Trump and as participants also reacted to better than expected lending data. Elsewhere, KLCI (+0.4%) saw an early slump with losses of over 2% on reopen from the surprise election result, but then pared all the weakness as the fears of a new government gradually subsided. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat amid similar price action in T-notes and with demand sapped amid gains in stocks, while downside was also counterbalanced by the BoJ’s presence in the market for a respectable JPY 1.03tln of JGBs in 1yr-10yr maturities.

PBoC skipped reverse repo operations and instead announced to lend CNY 156bln via 1yr Medium-term Lending Facility at 3.3% which effectively rolled over same maturing amount, while it conducted CNY 80.1bln in PSL loans. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3345 (Prev. 6.3524)

US President Trump said he instructed the US Commerce Department to assist Chinese telecoms firm ZTE to get back into business which is seen as a U-turn on the firm which was previously placed under a 7-year supply ban by the US. (FT)

GEOPOLITICS

Iranian foreign minister Zarif says had good meetings with China and Russian counterparts, adding they will soon determine how nations can guarantee Iran’s benefit under the nuclear deal. (Newswires)

North Korea is planning to take apart its nuclear test site during a ceremony to be held between May 23rd-25th, while there were also comments from US Secretary of State Pompeo that North Korea sanctions will be lifted if the nation proceeds with total denuclearizarion of the Korean peninsula. (Newswires/CBS)

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed's Mester (Voter, Hawk) said she doesn’t expect inflation to pick up sharply and she supports gradual rise in US interest rates and adds she does not expect to hike rates beyond 3% in the near future. (Newswires/CNBC)

ECB's Villeroy (Dovish) said the end of net asset purchases is nearing, but whether this is in September of December is not an existential question, adding that communication will be adjusted given current rate guidance is conditioned on the end of net asset purchases, could give additional guidance on timing of rate hike - "well past" seeming some quarters rather than years. He believes underlying inflation is set to strengthen irrespective of short-run fluctuations in energy inflation, sees the current slowdown in inflation as temporary and expects it to resume its progress in the coming months. (Newswires)

Norges bank Governor Olsen reiterates outlook shows it will be the right time to hike key interest rates soon; adding that their latest analyses presented in March 2018 suggest that the key interest rate will likely be raised after summer 2018. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

Italy’s 5-Star Movement and League reportedly reached an agreement on measures including universal basic income, a flat tax and roll back of pension reforms from 2011. Reports also stated that the agreement is likely to underpin the formation of a government although they still need to reach a deal on who to choose to be PM and cabinet members. Reports from Corriere state Italy’s League has proposed Giulio Sapelli as PM and 5 Star proposes Giuseppe Conte (WSJ/Corriere)

Note: Italian President Mattarella to hold government formation talks with 5 Star at 16:30 (15:30 BST), with League at 18:00 (17:00 BST)

UK PM May spokesman states that there is no timeline for defining the details of the two options for the future customs relationship with the EU, priority is getting things right. (Newswires)

Divisions in the UK cabinet were exposed again yesterday as Jeremy Hunt told fellow ministers to trust Theresa May’s Brexit plan, but Michael Gove said that there were “significant question marks” over her preferred customs model. (Times)

The EU is to look for an optional six-month extension to the Brexit transition period to be built in to the UK’s withdrawal agreement. (Independent)

EQUITIES

European equities are currently trading with no firm directions (Euro Stoxx 50 -0.1%) with the SMI the outperforming bourse (+0.3%) aided by Novartis (+0.8%) and Roche (+1.2%) both receiving positive news from the FDA pertaining to drug expansions. The modestly underperforming bourse is currently the FTSE MIB (-0.5%) with traders mindful of upcoming developments on the Italian Government formation.

The automotive sector is being weighed on following the US proposition of 20% tariffs of foreign cars imported to the US.

Further effects in European equities from US actions has seen the healthcare sector showing positivity in the wake of the Trump administration releasing a (vague) blueprint for drug pricing; and Ericsson and Nokia down on Trump’s tweet that he will help the penalized ZTE.

In stock specifics, strength is being seen for IWG (+21.2%) on the news that the co. has received separate takeover proposals from private equity groups Starwood, Lone Star and TDR Capital, raising prospects of a bidding war.

FX

EUR/GBP

Leading broad gains vs the Dollar on a combination of supportive fundamentals (relatively hawkish rhetoric from ECB’s Villeroy and further progress towards an Italian coalition Government in the case of the single currency), and a more positive technical landscape after recent sharp declines. It appears that Eur/Usd and Cable have both formed fairly solid bases circa 1.1820 and 1.3460 respectively, and dip-buyers/fresh longs are looking for extended recoveries towards 1.2000 and 1.3600 with stops said to be poised around 1.1980 and 1.3610. Market contacts also note that chart resistance in Eur/Jpy has been breached at 130.86, with bulls eyeing a 50% Fib next (131.86 vs 131.20 top so far).

CAD/AUD/CHF

All mildly firmer vs the aforementioned depressed Greenback overall (index still sub-92.500), with the Loonie still benefiting from latest NAFTA reports suggesting a deal could be forthcoming by Thursday and Usd/Cad retesting bids/support ahead of 1.2750. Aud/Usd is maintaining recovery momentum around 0.7550 amidst less against on the global trade front after US President Trump’s volte-face on China’s ZTE, and with cross Aud/Nzd also a prop (over 1.0850 and edging towards the 200 DMA at 108.81). Usd/Chf is holding just below parity, prompting more pledges from the SNB to keep rates negative and active in terms of direct FX intervention to curb Franc demand/appreciation.

NZD/JPY

The G10/major laggards and bucking the overall trend with losses vs the Usd, albeit modest, as the Kiwi hovers near 0.6950 and Usd/Jpy rebounds from the low 109.00 area to 109.50.

NOK

Briefly extended recent gains vs the Eur on more hawkish guidance from the Norges Bank, but now losing some ground within a 9.5340-5740 range.

FIXED INCOME

As noted from the outset, Bunds have looked increasingly leggy above 159.00 in recent sessions and amidst hawkish-leaning ECB commentary courtesy of Villeroy the technical picture has turned more bearish as a series of recent lows failed to hold. The first to go was last Friday’s Eurex session base at 158.79, and then an interim chart support at 158.68 gave way ahead of last week’s low at 158.52, with a Fib at 158.43 also unable to arrest the slide as the core Eurozone bond slips to 158.26 (-59 ticks). Bears are now eyeing 158.20 before 158.00, while Gilts have now been down to 121.65 (-45 ticks) and just through a ‘strong’ downside technical level at 121.67, with 121.50 next on the radar. US Treasuries largely side-lined, but unable to escape the selling pressure that has built in EU debt peers, with the curve re-steepening after, amidst and ahead of multiple Fed speakers including Mester. Note, fixed also faced with a heavy corporate deal pipeline and impending long end DMO Gilt supply.

COMMODITIES

Moving onto the commodities complex, oil prices are lower, subdued on continued profit taking with WTI crude below the USD 71.00/bbl level, while some reports also noting increased efforts by European nations to salvage the Iranian nuclear deal and will be meeting with Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif tomorrow.

Elsewhere, gold trades flat with marginal gains observed on the back of a subdued USD, while copper (-0.5%) is lower amid reports Japanese miners plan to boost Chilean copper output this year. Aluminium prices eased for a third session as markets continue to correct following the rally last month supported by US sanctions against Rusal. Meanwhile, Chinese iron ore prices extended gains, supported by a firm demand outlook and a decline in the metal’s inventories at ports

Note: OPEC Monthly report to be released at 05:40 CDT (11:40 BST)

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
14th May 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week mostly positive but with trade relatively rangebound following Friday’s mixed performance on Wall St, where stocks saw an indecisive finish to their best week since March. In addition, US equity futures also received a modest uplift after US President Trump provided a lifeline for ZTE over the weekend as he vowed to get the Chinese telco back to business in a surprising policy U-turn after the Co. had announced a halt to major operating activities following a US 7-year supply ban order. ASX 200 (+0.3%) was positive with M&A activity underpinning Healthscope, while Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) was also in the green as earnings remained in focus with Shiseido among the index leaders on record Q1 sales. Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) and Hang Seng (+1.5%) conformed to the broad risk appetite as trade concerns eased following the ZTE policy reversal by Trump and as participants also reacted to better than expected lending data. Elsewhere, KLCI (+0.4%) saw an early slump with losses of over 2% on reopen from the surprise election result, but then pared all the weakness as the fears of a new government gradually subsided. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat amid similar price action in T-notes and with demand sapped amid gains in stocks, while downside was also counterbalanced by the BoJ’s presence in the market for a respectable JPY 1.03tln of JGBs in 1yr-10yr maturities.

FTSE

UK gambling names – UK government is set to unveil a shake-up of fixed-odds betting terminals (FOBT) shortly. Chief executive at William Hill (WMH LN) says the GBP 2 FOBT would mean half of UK’s betting shops facing threat of closure and about 20,000 job cuts. KPMG estimates the FOBT would cut Treasury revenue by GBP 1.1bln over three years. (BBC)

UK defence names – The defence secretary is expected to announce an investment of GBP 2.5bln in the UK’s nuclear submarine programme. The announcement comes days after MPs criticised the Ministry of Defence’s “unrealistic” spending plans. (BBC)

Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA LN) / ENI (ENI IM) – Co.’s and a number of senior executives at the two firms face trial over corruption charges relation to a USD 1.1bln deal for a Nigerian oil block. (The Independent)

IWG (IWG LN) – Co. has received separate takeover proposals from private equity groups Starwood, Lone Star and TDR Capital, raising prospects of a bidding war. Co. said there was no certainty any offers would be made and that its board was evaluating the possible offers with financial advisers. Private equity firms have until June 8 to make a firm offer for the Co. under the UK’s takeover code. (FT)

WPP (WPP LN) – Ex AOL chief executive was named as potential successor of Martin Sorrell. The co. is also facing backlash after the co.’s ousting of Sorrell after an advisory group recommended that investors oppose his re-election in the next AGM. Glass Lewis recommends holders vote against retaining Roberto Quarta as WPP Group Chairman (FT/Times/Newswires) 

Talk Talk (TALK LN) – The co. and Virgin Media are working on a deal to share the cost of new broadband networks. (Telegraph)

BROKER MOVES

MARKS & SPENCER (MKS LN) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT HSBC

DAX

Bayer (BAYN GY) – The synergies from buying rival Monsanto will be less that USD 1.5bln because of antitrust divestments. (Newswires)

Daimler (DAI GY) – German regulator BaFin is reviewing whether to place fines after it found that transactions being made to buy a 9.6% stake in Daimler should have been disclosed earlier. (Newswires)

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) – CEO Diess had been told of the potential costs of diesel emission cheating almost a month before investors were informed. VW says the size of the fine was not known at the time. (Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Co. shakes up management of its largest unit, the corporate and investment banking division as new CEO Sewing aims to turnaround the lossmaking company. (FT)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Innogy (IGY GY) – Q1 adj. net profit -10.8% at EUR 610mln vs. Exp. EUR 615mln. Q1 adj. EBIT -2% at EUR 1.24bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.21bln. Q1 adj. EBITDA -2.2% at EUR 1.58bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.58bln. Co. still expects adj. EBIT of around EUR 2.7bln in 2018, in-line with expectations. Co. still expects adj. net profit of over EUR 1.1bln in 2018 vs. Exp. EUR 1.13bln. (Newswires)

K+S (SDF GY) – Q1 revenues +4% to EUR 1.17bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.22bln, EBITDA +12% to EUR 237mln. Exp. for EBIT EUR 150mln. FY guidance confirmed. (Newswires)

CAC

Telecom Italia (TIT IM) / Vivendi (VIV FP) – Vivendi has notified Consob that it no longer controls Telecom Italia. Separately, Vincent Bollore has raised his stake in Vivendi to more than 24%. (Newswires)

PAN EUROPE

EDP (EDP PL) – The Chinese group which included Three Gorges is preparing a EUR 9bln bid for the co. (Expresso)

ABN AMRO (ABN NA) – Q1 net profit EUR 595mln vs. Exp. EUR 557mln, operating income EUR 2.33bln vs. Exp. EUR 2.19bln, FY guidance confirmed. (Newswires)

Mediaset (MS IM) – Italian antitrust agency is deciding whether to open an investigation into the Mediaset-Sky Italia cooperation in the coming days. (Corriere Della Sera)

Telefonica (TEF SM) – Criteria are reportedly purchasing shares in the Co. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA

BROKER MOVES

BOLIDEN (BOL SS) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OUTPERFORM AT CREDIT SUISSE

SMI

Novartis (NOVN SW) – The FDA has expanded the co.’s use of MS drug Gilenya, which is the first MS adolescent drug that can be used for relapsing MS. (Newswires)

Roche (ROG SW) – FDA approves additional claim for Co’s cobas Zika test which allows for streamlined screening of pooled plasma or blood donations. This follows updated industry recommendations for screening US blood supply for Zika virus. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SIKA (SIK SW) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT CREDIT SUISSE

RICHEMONT (CFR SW) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT HSBC

US

* EQUITIES: SPX +0.17% at 2728, NDX -0.16% at 6953, DJI+0.37% at 24830. SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals: +0.13%, Cons, Non-Cyclicals: +0.15%, Energy: +0.02%, Financials: -0.22%,Health Care: +1.50%, Industrials: +0.14%, Materials: -0.06%,Technology: -0.39%, Telecoms: +2.04%, Utilities: +0.18%.

US President Trump’s administration released a blueprint on Friday for how it intends to lower drug prices in which Trump stated they are eliminating the middlemen in the drug industry who have become rich. Furthermore, Trump stated he instructed officials to bring soaring drug prices back to earth and that a pricing plan will encourage drugmakers to keep prices low. (Newswires)

Divisions in the UK cabinet were exposed again yesterday as Jeremy Hunt told fellow ministers to trust Theresa May’s Brexit plan but Michael Gove said that there were “significant question marks” over her preferred customs model. (Times)

The EU is to look for an optional six-month extension to the Brexittransition period to be built in to the UK’s withdrawal agreement. (Independent) 

EU Brexit Negotiator Barnier sees a risk that Brexit talks will fail, according to reports on Friday. (Spiegel)
 

EU

Italy’s 5-Star Movement and League reportedly reached an agreement on measures including universal basic income, a flat tax and roll back of pension reforms from 2011. Reports also stated that the agreement is likely to underpin the formation of a government although they still need to reach a deal on who to choose to be PM and cabinet members. (WSJ)

Norges Bank Governor Olsen writes in op-ed that outlook demonstrates it will soon be correct to raise rates. (Newswires)
 

FX

In FX markets, the greenback was somewhat subdued with the DXY below 92.50 in a continuation of last week’s inflation-provoked pullback and amid the backdrop of Trump policy uncertainty. This benefitted its major counterparts EUR/USD and GBP/USD in which the former was also facilitated by news that Italy’s 5-Star Movement and League reached an agreement which is likely to pave the way for the formation of a government, while a subdued commodities complex kept trade in related currencies indecisive. Elsewhere, MYR saw volatile trade as participants reacted to the regime change in Malaysia which saw the currency slip to a 4-month low on the initial shock before it mounted a recovery, while NOK was underpinned in late trade after Norges Bank Governor Olsen suggested in an op-ed that it will soon be appropriate to lift rates.

SNB's Zurbruegg said the CHF can quickly strengthen, while he added that there is no need to give up negative interest rates and does not see a need to give up FX market intervention. (Newswires)


COMMODITIES

Commodities traded mixed with oil prices subdued on continued profit taking in which WTI crude extended further below the USD 71.00/bbl level, while some reports also noted increased efforts by European nations to salvage the Iranian nuclear deal and will be meeting with Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif tomorrow. Elsewhere, gold traded flat with marginal gains observed on the back of a subdued USD, while copper also remained afloat alongside the positive risk tone. (Newswires)

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count (4 May) 1045 (Prev. 1032). (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

North Korea is planning to take apart its nuclear test site during a ceremony to be held between May 23rd-25th, while there were also comments from US Secretary of State Pompeo that North Korea sanctions will be lifted if the nation proceeds with total denuclearizarion of the Korean peninsula. (Newswires/CBS)
 

US

The curve flattened to fresh decade narrows on Friday (5s30s); however, when the dust settled, Friday action was uneventful, and yields were little changed. At the end of the week, a June hike is completely priced (100%) rising around 5ppts in the week, according to the CME Fedwatch data. Heading into the cash open, Treasuries found sellers, with the 10yr T-Note future hitting session lows before ticking higher gradually as the cash equity day got underway. Nonetheless the moves were relatively range-bound as volume was hardly spectacular heading to the weekend, and following yesterday’s softer CPI prints. * FOREX: *DXY: The index ended. US 10yr T-Notes futures settled half a tick higher at 119-13.

US President Trump's administration released a blueprint on Friday for how it intends to lower drug prices in which Trump stated they are eliminating the middlemen in the drug industry who have become rich. Furthermore, Trump stated he instructed officials to bring soaring drug prices back to earth and that a pricing plan will encourage drugmakers to keep prices low. (Newswires)

Canada's Foreign Minister Freeland said meaningful progress has been made by the three NAFTA sides last week. There were also comments from Mexican Economy Minister Guajardo who stated that the NAFTA meeting was efficient and that ministers are working to reach a NAFTA deal by 17th May. (Newswires)

subject: Malaysia Finance Ministry confirms to scrap the Goods and Services tax, adds new government will not place any new taxes for 2 years
China is to restart its assessment on the Qualcomm (QCOM) deal to acquire NXP Semiconductors (NXPI)
ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks traded higher as trade concerns eased following Trump policy U-turn on China's ZTE
content: Asia equity markets began the week mostly positive but with trade relatively rangebound following Friday’s mixed performance on Wall St, where stocks saw an indecisive finish to their best week since March. In addition, US equity futures also received a modest uplift after US President Trump provided a lifeline for ZTE over the weekend as he vowed to get the Chinese telco back to business in a surprising policy U-turn after the Co. had announced a halt to major operating activities following a US 7-year supply ban order. ASX 200 (+0.3%) was positive with M&A activity underpinning Healthscope after it received an unsolicited proposal from Brookfield and with GWA the outperformer on news it is to offload a unit, while Nikkei 225 (+0.4) was also in the green as earnings remained in focus with Shiseido among the index leaders on record Q1 sales. Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) and Hang Seng (+1.5%) conformed to the broad risk appetite as trade concerns eased following the ZTE policy reversal by Trump and as participants also reacted to better than expected lending data. Elsewhere, KLCI (+0.4%) saw an early slump with losses of over 2% on reopen from the surprise election result, but then pared all the weakness as the fears gradually eased. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat amid similar price action in T-notes and with demand sapped amid gains in stocks, while downside was also counterbalanced by the BoJ’s presence in the market for a respectable JPY 1.03tln of JGBs in 1yr-10yr maturities.
